And the World Listened
1:30 P.M. Sunday
Repeated 7:30 P.M. Monday
These programs focus attention on some of the
celebrated orators of history whose thoughts and
utterances have helped to shape some of the ideas and
institutions which constitute Western Civilization.
Consultant for the series is Professor Frederick W.
Haberman, chairman of the speech department at the
University of Wisconsin. The series was produced by
Station WHA for broadcast throughout the U. S. by
affiliated stations of the National Association of Edu¬
cational Broadcasters. The programs were directed by
Karl Schmidt.
May 4, 5
William Pitt, Earl of Chatham (1708-1778)—The
Attempt to Subjugate America. Chatham’s speeches
on America concern liberty, government by con¬
stitution, and the misery of war. This speech con¬
tains the famous passage: "If I were an American,
as I am an Englishman, while a foreign troop was
landed in my country, I never would lay down my
arms—never—never—never!”
May 11, 12
Edmund Burke (1730-1797)—Conciliation With
America. A master of metaphor, of coherent de¬
sign, and of political philosophy, Burke was at his
best in the Conciliation speech. The theme of the
speech is that "taxation and representation are in¬
separably conjoined,” and that magnanimity in
politics is needful in holding a great empire
together.
May 18, 1S>
Daniel O’Connell (1775-1847)—Irish Independ¬
ence. Over a million people were said to have
gathered at Tara in Ireland on August 15, 1843
to hear Daniel O’Connell speak for Irish Inde¬
pendence. Called The Liberator, it is not an ex¬
aggeration to say that O’Connell spoke to and for
all of Ireland.
May 25, 26
Daniel Webster (1782-1852)—The Knapp Mur¬
der Trial. Among Daniel Webster’s forensic ad¬
dresses the speeches delivered on the trial of Frank
Knapp for the murder of Captain White of Salem
are the most famous. The reconstructed summation
speech is well known for its narrative passages. Not
so well known is the fact that it goes beyond the
evidence in obtaining the conviction.
June 1, 2
Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865)—Lincoln-Douglas
Debates. These debates have drama because of the
protagonists themselves, as well as because of the
historic importance of the subject which was, ulti¬
mately, the survival of slavery in the United States.
June 8, 9
Booker T. Washington (1858-1915)—Atlanta In¬
ternational Exposition. Booker T. Washington was a
powerful speaker, one of the most accomplished of
his day. For over thirty years he was in constant
demand until his death in 1915. He was an
acknowledged leader of the Negro race in America
and one of the outstanding men of our country.
June 15, 16
Elizabeth Cady Stanton (1815-1915)—The Right
to Hold Property. First president of the National
American Woman Suffrage Association, Elizabeth
Cady Stanton was an eloquent spokesman of wom¬
en’s rights. In the legislature of her native state
of New York, she began the fight for the right of
women to hold property after marriage.
June 22, 23
Winston Churchill (1871-——)—The Battle of
Britain. Replete with celebrated passages, this
speech has as its general theme the protection of
the home land and the survival of freedom. The
stirring words reveal much about the orator, his
sense of history, his imaginative grasp of the fearful
struggle, and his awe-inspiring courage.
June 29, 30
Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1882-1945)—The
Four Freedoms. The message to Congress contain¬
ing the philosophy and the description of the four
freedoms is one of Roosevelt’s most eloquent and
most influential speeches. Its themes have become
ideals for this century.

A series of selected lectures from an all-University
course for senior students, broadcast from a class¬
room on the Madison campus of the University of
Wisconsin. The course presents a non-technical con¬
sideration of the physical and social sciences, em¬
phasizing national and international problems.

The Words We Use
10:30 A.M. Tuesday
Repeated 9:00 A.M. Saturday
Professor Frederick Cassidy
of the department of English at
the University of Wisconsin
presents weekly discussions on
words, phrases, sayings, usage,
and pronunciation. Professor
Cassidy is a well known scholar
and researcher. For many years
he has been conducting the
Wisconsin English Language
Survey which seeks to study
all the characteristics of Ameri¬
can English as it is used in this state. As a part of
this survey he conducted the radio program Wiscon¬
sin Words a few years ago on the state stations. It
is expected that the book based on these studies, to
be entitled Wisconsin Words, will be published by
1959- Professor Cassidy is now engaged in a study
of the English language as it is spoken in Jamaica.
The Words We Use is an entertaining and in¬
structive program and has attracted a wide audience
this semester.
